mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Violence and Destruction of the Russian Civil War
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Doctor Zhivago by Boris Pasternak and the White Guard by Mikhail Bulgakov

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This thesis analyzes the violence and destruction of the Russian Civil War through the novels The White Guard by Mikhial Bulgakov and Doctor Zhivago by Boris Pasternak. Comparing The White Guard and Doctor Zhivago to each other, while using non-fictional sources to supplement the chaos and terror in the Russian Civil War. Starting with a description of the two authors, Boris Pasternak and Mikhail Bulgakov, discussing their backgrounds, theology, personal beliefs and their other literary works that may have played a role in the development of their novels on the Civil War. The next chapter is focused on the theme of impending death in the Russian Civil War, analyzes Bulgakov's and Pasternak's use of religious motifs, apocalyptic imagery and fear that is brewing in the characters. The chaos is amplified with the arrival of barbaric groups, new ideologies and the news of death looming on the horizon. Chapter three discusses the barbarity of the Russian Civil War through the depiction of violence towards civilians, focusing on state sponsored atrocities against innocents, the killing of ethnic minorities, the prevalence of anti-Semitism in this conflict and the barbarity of war. Combining these horrors with non-fictional works to have statistics on crimes and investigate the use of militaries against civilians in historical texts for a better understanding of the barbarity of the Civil War. Chapter four of this thesis covers the battle of the ideologies. This being the coverage and analysis of both The White Guard and Doctor Zhivago to display the violence and the rhetoric used by both sides to justify violence or to recreate society. The early 20th century of Russia was filled with a multitude of socialist ideologies that sought to uproot the yolk of Russian conservatism, the Romanov dynasty. Analyzing the violence and the destructive nature of the Bolsheviks and monarchists, piecing together what Bulgakov and Pasternak thought of both the Russian intelligentsia and the exploited Russian poor to have an understanding of why people fought for certain ideologies. The comparison of both fiction and non-fiction is necessary in understanding the extent of the barbarity in the Russian Civil War. This comparison will give an understanding of what went on in the different theatres of war during this conflict, from the Ural-Siberian theatre to Moscow and the perspective of Kiev, this conflict that was spread out over five thousand miles and I will compare The White Guard and Doctor Zhivago to investigate the struggles characters experienced and the chaos that ensued. The findings of this thesis will help illustrate The White Guard and Doctor Zhivago's themes of destructive ideologies, chaos of the Russian Civil War and the suffering of this period in history. In conclusion, the barbarity of war enveloped the entirety of Russia, leaving no piece of land untouched and no soul undisturbed by the events of the Civil War. The White Guard and Doctor Zhiavgo are all encompassing novels revealing the immensity of this conflict that I dissect and analyze similarities in suffering, chaos and ideological struggles throughout these works.
